channel.title: Twitch Plays Pokemon!
channel.description:
I'm not sure if anyone here has heard of this yet, but twitch.tv is doing a special Twitch Plays Pokemon series where they have an open Pokemon source play for the viewers on the Red game in which the viewers control the character. It's basically over 80,000 people trying to control the same exact character at once and make their way through he game. They've been playing for 8 days straight now and have only gotten 4 gym badges lol.... Super entertaining trying to watch them maneuver.
Check it out @ http://www.twitch.tv/twitchplayspokemon

item.title: Twitch Plays Pokemon!
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

eyeownyew:

To be fair, Rodger, if they had an infinite number of monkeys, something identical to Shakespeare’s works would be produced instantly. So, there’s that.

Go to where I got that quote from and point it out or get the fk off.

Read full topic

item.title: Twitch Plays Pokemon!
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:22, topic:540423”]Are you guys trying to argue about my comment? :palm:

Quote from Twitch.tv - [quote]It was created as an experiment [/quote]

There is a reason TwitchPlaysPokemon, the created it because they wanted to see what would happen. It’s obviously a social experiment, why do I need to show proof of this because a social experiment when it’s quite obvious? “Coca Cola - cameras around the world” is a social experiment and there isn’t really any reasoning behind it. That’s the beauty of social experiment. You’re more than welcome to predict an outcome but there is no control. Individuals will have their own feelings based on how the perceive it. Some will think it’s awesome and others… well haters gonna hate.

So, what does the great social experiment that is Twitch Plays Pokemon teach us about human nature? The biggest message seems to be that people will naturally seek out order from chaos through cooperation and democracy if given the right tools.

[quote]It was French mathematician Émile Borel who first hypothesized that if you took an infinite number of monkeys and sat them down in front of typewriters that they might eventually produce something resembling the works of William Shakespeare. His theory is known as the Infinite Monkey Theorem and it’s an exercise in probability.

For instance, a more modern take on the question might be: if you took 70,000 people and sat them all down to play one video game together, could they beat it?

We may be about to find out.[/quote][/quote]
To be fair, Rodger, if they had an infinite number of monkeys, something identical to Shakespeare’s works would be produced instantly. So, there’s that.

Read full topic

item.title: Twitch Plays Pokemon!
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

Are you guys trying to argue about my comment? :palm:

Quote from Twitch.tv -

It was created as an experiment

There is a reason TwitchPlaysPokemon, the created it because they wanted to see what would happen. It’s obviously a social experiment, why do I need to show proof of this because a social experiment when it’s quite obvious? “Coca Cola - cameras around the world” is a social experiment and there isn’t really any reasoning behind it. That’s the beauty of social experiment. You’re more than welcome to predict an outcome but there is no control. Individuals will have their own feelings based on how the perceive it. Some will think it’s awesome and others… well haters gonna hate.

So, what does the great social experiment that is Twitch Plays Pokemon teach us about human nature? The biggest message seems to be that people will naturally seek out order from chaos through cooperation and democracy if given the right tools.
It was French mathematician Émile Borel who first hypothesized that if you took an infinite number of monkeys and sat them down in front of typewriters that they might eventually produce something resembling the works of William Shakespeare. His theory is known as the Infinite Monkey Theorem and it’s an exercise in probability.

For instance, a more modern take on the question might be: if you took 70,000 people and sat them all down to play one video game together, could they beat it?

We may be about to find out.

Read full topic

item.title: Twitch Plays Pokemon!
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:20, topic:540423”][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=659281.msg4409775#msg4409775 date=1393183052]
I never said that there needs to be an aim.
[/quote][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=659281.msg4409775#msg4409775 date=1393183052]there must be an aim.
[/quote]
You’re cute[/quote]

Why not actually quote things with the context that they were said in? Oh, of course, because that would mean that the messages say what I actually said, rather than what you want them to say.

Ambokile:

I never said that there needs to be an aim. He called it an experiment. If it is an experiment, there must be an aim. It isn’t an experiment.

Nice try, but not quite enough effort. Sorry mate

Read full topic

item.description:

item.title: Twitch Plays Pokemon!
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

John:

What sort of aim does there have to be? As I said it’s just for the fun of seeing people work together or against each other to play a pokemon game. Why does there need to be a conclusion or purpose?

Are you reading the same words that I am writing? I never said that there needs to be an aim. However, he called it an experiment. If it is an experiment, there must be an aim. I asked him what aim he feels there is, if it is an experiment. It may be something cool, but it isn’t an experiment.

Read full topic

item.title: Twitch Plays Pokemon!
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:16, topic:540423”][quote author=John link=topic=659281.msg4409759#msg4409759 date=1393178676][quote]
Without resorting to “Haters gonna hate”, please explain to me the aims of the experiment and why this method was the best method to achieve those aims.
[/quote]
Why does there need to be some “aims to the experiment” and what relevance does “having a better way” have? This isn’t some experiment by a prestigious college, it’s just for the fun of seeing so many people trying to handle one character in a pokemon game.
[/quote]

He claimed it was a “great experiment”, and I am disputing that. If the believes it to be an experiment, then surely he can tell me the aims of said experiment?[/quote]
It’s a sociology experiment. The aim? To see if mass amounts of people can cooperate and complete the given goal. It doesn’t need to be any more than that. Why should it be?

Read full topic

item.title: Twitch Plays Pokemon!
item.dc:creator: @Flame3 John
item.description:
@Flame3 wrote:

the elve age:

This is a stupid idea, why would anyone want to watch or play this?

The same reason anyone would play any other games, just to enjoy it.
I watched for a little while the other day, it’s cool seeing so many people trying to manage one game character.

Without resorting to "Haters gonna hate", please explain to me the aims of the experiment and why this method was the best method to achieve those aims.
Why does there need to be some "aims to the experiment" and what relevance does "having a better way" have? This isn't some experiment by a prestigious college, it's just for the fun of seeing so many people trying to handle one character in a pokemon game.

Read full topic

item.title: Twitch Plays Pokemon!
item.dc:creator: @Elrick Elrick
item.description:
@Elrick wrote:

the elve age:

This is a stupid idea, why would anyone want to watch or play this?

I honestly don’t know. Apparently there are thousands of people trying to command a bot to do things. I just like watching the chaos ensue from the comfort of Imgur.

Read full topic

item.title: Twitch Plays Pokemon!

item.description:
@nolan2131 wrote:
